newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: PRESS DIGEST - Sri Lanka Newspapers - June 18.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Sri Lanka Newspapers - June 18.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sri Lankan press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

Former United National Party (UNP) minister Sirisena Cooray, arrested under the country's emergency laws on Monday, is being questioned by the Criminal Investigation Department (CID). Police has still not said what the charges are against Cooray, who was a high-profile minister in the late president Ranasinghe Premadasa's cabinet.
Sri Lankan Prime Minister Sirima Bandaranaike returns to Colombo after receiving medical treatment in China. While there, she also met top Chinese leaders and Communist Party officials.

The Colombo port sets a record by handling 660,927 TEU's (Twenty-foot equivalent units) in the first five months of this year, against a total one million TEUs in 1996. Colombo is a major transshipment port for the south Asian region.
The Criminal Investigation Department has launched a full-scale inquiry into the activities of former minister Sirisena Cooray. Three more politicians are likely to be arrested for questioning.

Sri Lanka expects to attract at least 400,000 tourists this year after a sharp drop in arrivals last year. Latest statistics show that there was an increase of nearly 27 percent in tourist arrivals in May, over the same period last year.
Police department plans to take 48 policemen and officers to court for dereliction of duty.

A suspect in the killing of Nalanda Ellawala, parliament deputy of the ruling People's Alliance (PA) coalition, has been released on bail by a court in southern Ratnapura. Ellawala was killed in February during a roadside brawl.
Srimani Athulathmudali, leader of DUNLF, a PA constituent, who was sacked from her ministerial post by President Chandrika Kumaratunga last week, says she is not worried about losing her job.
Prime Minister Sirima Bandaranaike returns to Sri Lanka after medical treatment in China.
Suspected Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebels blow up an electricity transformer near eastern Trincomalee.
The new Transport Minister A.H.M. Fowzie says there will be no increase in bus and rail fares.
